columns.text: The goal of this task is to explain the criteria of the Internal Revenue Service to determine if a lease is tax deductible.

First, let's remember that the **Internal Revenue Service** (IRS) is the government agency charged with collecting taxes and ensuring that tax laws are properly enforced.  

With this in mind, it is clear that the IRS will be very interested in knowing the details of leases to identify whether the lease contacts have a business purpose or whether the primary purpose is tax evasion.

There are transactions that IRS identifies as sales or exchanges, transactions on which tax will be owed. These include: 

**Sale through a lease**. Some agreements that appear to be leases may be conditional sale contracts. There is no standard for determining which lease agreement may represent a sale; one must know the intentions of the parties as reflected in the lease agreements. 

Now, in IRS Publication 535, we have a section entitled: **Taxes on Leased Property**, where we can see that payments made to the lessor for taxes may be deducted on the lessee's tax return. It also clarifies that the law of each state and the lease itself determines the liability and amount of taxes.

Now, it is also important to know about the impact of the cancellation of a lease on taxes. When lease termination payments are received, they are treated as an amount realized on the sale of the property. 

On the other hand, payments received by a lessor for the cancellation of a lease are considered a substitute for rental payments and are taxed as ordinary income in the year in which they are received.
